metadata.titleEn: Quantifying the rise of the Himalaya orogen and implications for the South Asian monsoon
metadata.description: This data set is from the paper: Ding, L., Spicer, R.A., Yang, J., Xu, Q., Cai, F.L., Li, S., Lai, q.z., Wang, H.Q., Spicer, t.e.v., Yue, Y.H., Shukla, A., Srivastava, g., Khan, M.A., BERA, S., and Mehrotra, R. 2017. Quantifying the rise of the Himalaya origin and implications for the South Asian monsoon. Geography, 45:215-218. This achievement is part of a series of research results of paleoaltitude carried out by Ding Lin' team. We reconstruct the rise of a segment of the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen, to the south of the Lhasa terrane, using a paleoaltimeter based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves from two new assemblages in southern Tibet (Liuqu and Qiabulin) and four previously known floras from the Himalaya foreland basin. U-Pb dating of zircons constrains the Liuqu flora to the latest Paleocene (ca. 56 Ma) and the Qiabulin flora to the earliest Miocene (21–19 Ma). The proto-Himalaya grew slowly against a high (~4 km) proto–Tibetan Plateau from ~1 km in the late Paleocene to ~2.3 km at the beginning of the Miocene, and achieved at least ~5.5 km by ca. 15 Ma. Contrasting precipitation patterns between the Himalaya-Tibet edifice and the Himalaya foreland basin for the past ~56 m.y. show  progressive drying across southern Tibet, seemingly linked to the uplift of the Himalaya orogen.
metadata.instructions:
The data is from the attachment of the paper. Data sets include
S1  geological and sedimentary setting
S3 Zircon U-Pb dating and depositional age constraints
S3 TABLES， including; U-Pb isotopic analysis of detrital zircons from Liuqu, Qiuwu and Dazuqu Formations, Major elements data for minerals comprising the tuffite by electron probe microanalysis, CLAMP scores describing woody dicot leaf form within the Liuqu, Qiuwu, Namling and India paleofloras, Climatic parameters predicted by CLAMP and their associated statistical uncertainties, Paleoelevation estimated by CLAMP,
S4 diagram, includingRepresentative leaf fossils from the Liuqu Formation, Gongjiongla and Za localities, Mean age diagram for a tuffite, Zircon U-Pb age probability density diagram, Diorite clasts from Liuqu conglomerate and zircon age diagram, Representative leaf fossils from the Qiuwu Formation, Field photographs, Annual average moist enthalpy at mean sea level

background: Quantifying the rise of the Himalaya since the onset of the collision of India with Asia at ca. 55 ± 10 Ma (Wang et al., 2014) has proved challenging and controversial (Garzione et al., 2000; Spicer et al., 2003; Currie et al., 2005; Rowley and Currie, 2006; DeCelles et al., 2007; Saylor et al., 2009; Ding et al., 2014), spurred on by the idea that changes in surface height, area, and surface characteristics of the Himalaya orogen and Tibetan Plateau underpin South Asian and East Asian monsoon dynamics (Molnar et al., 1993; Boos and Kuang, 2010). Opinions differ on how the plateau evolved, but modeling suggests that an orographic high such as the Himalaya may be more important than the elevation and/or extent of the entire plateau in shaping modern South Asian monsoon circulation (Boos and Kuang, 2010). Understanding the coupling between tectonics and climate requires quantification of elevation history, but to date little is known about the rise of the proto-Himalaya, with almost all the paleoaltimetry of different parts of the Himalayan chain only showing that it was near its present elevation by the late Miocene (Garzione et al., 2000; Saylor et al., 2009; Gébelin et al., 2013). In woody dicot angiosperms, evolutionary selection has resulted in a genome capable of producing highly variable leaf architecture optimized to local climate, and globally leaf form is more strongly linked to climate than taxonomic affinity (Yang et al., 2015). Unsurprisingly then, leaf form encodes the numerous climate metrics characteristic of monsoons (Spicer et al., 2016) as well as moist enthalpy, an expression of both atmospheric temperature and moisture that varies with elevation (Forest et al., 1999).
research objective: Here we introduce and date two fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections along the Yarlung-Zangpo suture (YZS) yielding the Liuqu and Qiabulin paleofloras, which together with a previously published 15 m.y. paleoflora from the Namling Basin, south Lhasa terrane (Spicer et al., 2003; Khan et al., 2014), and four sea-level floras of similar ages from Himalaya foreland basin (Srivastava et al., 2012; Khan et al., 2014; Shukla et al., 2014) allow us to chart elevation and climate change along the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen over the past ~56 m.y.
challenges: The minimum ~1 km descent of Namling since 15 Ma, due to extension along a north-south rift zone (Armijo et al., 1986), contrasts with the modern high Himalaya, as typified by Mount Everest, which has been maintained >5.0 km over the last 15 m.y. (Gébelin et al., 2013).
methods: We reconstruct the rise of a segment of the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen, to the south of the Lhasa terrane, using a paleoaltimeter based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves from two new assemblages in southern Tibet (Liuqu and Qiabulin) and four previously known floras from the Himalaya foreland basin. U-Pb dating of zircons constrains the Liuqu flora to the latest Paleocene (ca. 56 Ma) and the Qiabulin flora to the earliest Miocene (21–19 Ma).
findings: The proto-Himalaya grew slowly against a high (~4 km) proto–Tibetan Plateau from ~1 km in the late Paleocene to ~2.3 km at the beginning of the Miocene, and achieved at least ~5.5 km by ca. 15 Ma. Contrasting precipitation patterns between the Himalaya-Tibet edifice and the Himalaya foreland basin for the past ~56 m.y. show progressive drying across southern Tibet, seemingly linked to the uplift of the Himalaya orogen.

Verification.Question: Is the paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves an effective method for reconstructing historical elevation changes in the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Can U-Pb dating of zircons be reliably used to constrain the ages of plant fossil-bearing sedimentary sections in this domain?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the main challenge in quantifying the rise of the Himalaya associated with the dating accuracy of fossil records, the variability of climate models, or other factors?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections located that provide data for charting elevation and climate change along the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to quantify elevation history in the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used in this field is the use of fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections, where paleoaltimetry is based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves. This method was applied to new assemblages in southern Tibet, such as Liuqu and Qiabulin, along with previously known floras from the Himalaya foreland basin.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when reconstructing the elevation history of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Example.Answer: A notable challenge is the minimum ~1 km descent of the Namling region since 15 Ma due to extension along a north-south rift zone, which contrasts with the modern high Himalaya that has maintained elevations over 5.0 km for the last 15 million years.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that might be used to study the climate changes associated with the uplift of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Example.Answer: Although specific datasets are not detailed, the study of elevation and climate change could use data from the fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections along the Yarlung-Zangpo suture, with U-Pb dating of zircons constraining specific floras like Liuqu and Qiabulin, which provide insights into past climate conditions.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining characteristics of paleoaltimetry techniques used in reconstructing elevation history?
Feature Specification.Answer: fossil leaves, climate-sensitive architecture of plant leaves, fossilized plant assemblages, U-Pb zircon dating

Feature Specification.Question: What are the essential features and attributes of a dataset used for analyzing the rise of mountain ranges and their climate interactions?
Feature Specification.Answer: fossil plant-bearing sedimentary sections, U-Pb zircon dating, climate metrics derived from leaf architecture, precipitation patterns over geological timescales

Quantification.Question: How many fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections were used to reconstruct the elevation history of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
What is the minimum elevation change recorded for the Namling area since 15 Ma due to geological processes?
What was the estimated height of the proto-Himalaya during the late Paleocene?

Definition.Question: What does 'paleoaltimeter' mean in the context of reconstructing historical elevation changes?
Definition.Answer: A paleoaltimeter is a tool or method used to estimate past elevations of land surfaces. In this context, it involves using paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves to reconstruct the historical rise of the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.

Definition.Question: What are 'paleoenthalpy' and its significance in paleoclimate studies?
Definition.Answer: Paleoenthalpy refers to the historical moisture and temperature content of the atmosphere as inferred from fossil evidence, such as leaf forms. It is significant in paleoclimate studies because it helps reconstruct past climate conditions and elevations, particularly in understanding how these factors influenced monsoon dynamics and tectonic interactions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in elevation history reconstruction between the proto-Himalaya and the proto-Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: The proto-Himalaya grew from ~1 km in the late Paleocene to ~2.3 km at the beginning of the Miocene, eventually reaching ~5.5 km by ca. 15 Ma. In contrast, the proto-Tibetan Plateau is described as maintaining a high elevation of approximately 4 km early on. This suggests slower initial growth for the proto-Himalaya compared to the more consistently high proto-Tibetan Plateau.

Comparison.Question: How do the precipitation patterns derived from the fossil record compare between the Himalaya-Tibet edifice and the Himalaya foreland basin over the past 56 million years?
Comparison.Answer: The fossil record indicates contrasting precipitation patterns, with the Himalaya-Tibet edifice experiencing progressive drying over southern Tibet linked to the uplift of the Himalaya orogen, while the Himalaya foreland basin shows different historical precipitation dynamics. This suggests a complex interaction between tectonic uplift and climate change across different regions.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the historical climate dynamics of South Asia by analyzing variations in fossil leaf architecture over millions of years?
Interpretation.Answer: Leaf form, which is strongly linked to climate, encodes climate metrics characteristic of monsoons and moist enthalpy, providing insights into historical climate dynamics as the Himalaya-Tibet orogen evolved.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in quantifying the rise of the Himalaya orogen and its implications for climate dynamics?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Quantifying the rise of the Himalaya since the onset of the collision of India with Asia has been challenging due to differing opinions on how the plateau evolved, the controversial nature of paleoaltimetry data, and the complex coupling between tectonics and climate. Modeling suggests that the orographic high of the Himalaya may be more important than the elevation of the entire plateau in shaping modern South Asian monsoon circulation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the reconstruction of elevation history using paleoaltimetry from fossil leaves considered a valuable method in this field?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Paleoaltimetry using fossil leaves is valuable because leaf form encodes climate metrics characteristic of monsoons and moist enthalpy, which varies with elevation. This method allows researchers to reconstruct the rise of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen by examining paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves, providing insights into elevation and climate change over millions of years.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the contrasting precipitation patterns between the Himalaya-Tibet edifice and the foreland basin, and how is it linked to the region's uplift?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The contrasting precipitation patterns are seemingly linked to the uplift of the Himalaya orogen, which has influenced the progressive drying across southern Tibet over the past 56 million years. The uplift may have altered atmospheric circulation and moisture distribution, contributing to these precipitation differences.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using paleoaltimetry based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves for understanding the historical uplift of mountain ranges?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using paleoaltimetry based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves allows researchers to reconstruct the historical rise of mountain ranges such as the Himalaya-Tibet orogen. This approach has uncovered that regions like the proto-Himalaya grew from ~1 km in the late Paleocene to ~2.3 km by the early Miocene, eventually reaching ~5.5 km by around 15 Ma. This data helps in understanding the tectonic evolution and its impact on climatic patterns over millions of years.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the application of U-Pb dating of zircons from plant fossil-bearing sedimentary sections influence the accuracy of reconstructing ancient elevations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The application of U-Pb dating of zircons enhances the accuracy of reconstructing ancient elevations by providing precise age constraints for plant fossil-bearing sedimentary sections. For instance, it helped date the Liuqu flora to the latest Paleocene (ca. 56 Ma) and the Qiabulin flora to the earliest Miocene (21–19 Ma), which are critical for understanding the timeline of elevation changes in the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind reconstructing the paleoaltimetry of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen using fossil plant assemblages?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to chart elevation and climate change along the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen over the past ~56 million years, providing insights into the coupling between tectonics and climate, and understanding the implications for South Asian monsoon dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of utilizing U-Pb dating of zircons in relation to fossil plant-bearing sedimentary sections along the Yarlung-Zangpo suture?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of using U-Pb dating of zircons is to constrain the ages of the Liuqu and Qiabulin paleofloras, which are essential for accurately reconstructing the timeline of elevation changes in the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to reconstruct paleoaltimetry using fossil leaves in the context of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The reconstruction of paleoaltimetry in the Himalaya-Tibet orogen is achieved using a paleoaltimeter based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves. This involves analyzing fossil plant assemblages from sedimentary sections and utilizing leaf form, which encodes climate metrics and moist enthalpy, to infer past elevations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is U-Pb dating used to constrain the age of fossil plant assemblages in geological studies of the Himalaya?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: U-Pb dating is used to constrain the age of fossil plant assemblages by dating zircons found within the sedimentary layers that contain the fossils. This method provides precise age estimates for the sedimentary sections, helping to establish a timeline for the rise of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the quantification of historical elevation changes in the Himalaya orogen over millions of years?
Enablement.Answer: The reconstruction of elevation changes is enabled by using paleoaltimeters based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves, combined with U-Pb dating of zircons to constrain the age of fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections.

Enablement.Question: How do fossil plant assemblages facilitate the understanding of climate dynamics in the context of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen?
Enablement.Answer: Fossil plant assemblages allow researchers to chart elevation and climate change along the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen by using variation in leaf architecture to infer climate metrics characteristic of monsoons and moist enthalpy variations with elevation.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of using U-Pb dating of zircons in understanding the elevation history of sedimentary sections in the Himalaya-Tibet region?
Expectation.Answer: The expected outcomes of using U-Pb dating of zircons include constraining the age of fossil plant-bearing sedimentary sections, such as dating the Liuqu flora to the latest Paleocene and the Qiabulin flora to the earliest Miocene, which helps in charting the elevation and climate change along the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.

Expectation.Question: Why might contrasting precipitation patterns between the Himalaya-Tibet edifice and the Himalaya foreland basin be significant in understanding the uplift history of the Himalaya orogen?
Expectation.Answer: Contrasting precipitation patterns are significant because they reveal progressive drying across southern Tibet, which appears to be linked to the uplift of the Himalaya orogen. This relationship helps in understanding the climatic impacts of tectonic changes over the past ~56 million years.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the use of paleoaltimetry based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves is in reconstructing historical elevation changes in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of paleoaltimetry based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves appears to be an effective method for reconstructing historical elevation changes, as it allows researchers to chart elevation and climate changes over millions of years by analyzing fossil plant data. This approach leverages the relationship between leaf form, climate, and elevation to deduce past altitudes and climatic conditions.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in applying U-Pb dating of zircons to constrain the ages of sedimentary sections in the context of elevation history reconstruction?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges in applying U-Pb dating of zircons include the need for precise dating to accurately constrain the ages of sedimentary sections, which is crucial for reconstructing elevation history. Additionally, it requires careful selection and analysis of zircon samples to ensure that they provide reliable age estimates that correlate with paleoaltimetry data.

Assertion.Question: I can't comprehend how paleoaltimetry techniques can accurately reconstruct the elevation history of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen over millions of years.
Assertion.Answer: The paleoaltimetry techniques used in this domain involve a paleoaltimeter based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves, which are dated using U-Pb dating of zircons. This method allows researchers to reconstruct the rise of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen by analyzing fossil plant–bearing sedimentary sections and their associated floras to determine past elevations and climate changes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how fossil plant data can provide insights into the ancient climate and monsoon patterns.
Assertion.Answer: Fossil plant data, particularly leaf architecture, is strongly linked to climate, more so than taxonomic affinity. Leaf form encodes numerous climate metrics characteristic of monsoons and moist enthalpy, which is an expression of atmospheric temperature and moisture that varies with elevation. This enables researchers to infer past climate conditions and monsoon dynamics.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used for reconstructing paleoaltimetry using plant fossils in the context of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involves using a paleoaltimeter based on paleoenthalpy encoded in fossil leaves. The researchers used plant fossil–bearing sedimentary sections to extract data on elevation history along the Yarlung-Zangpo suture. U-Pb dating of zircons was employed to date the Liuqu and Qiabulin paleofloras, constraining the Liuqu flora to the latest Paleocene (ca. 56 Ma) and the Qiabulin flora to the earliest Miocene (21–19 Ma).

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the challenges associated with dating fossilized plant assemblages to reconstruct the rise of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the challenges noted is the minimum ~1 km descent of Namling since 15 Ma, due to extension along a north-south rift zone. This contrasts with the modern high Himalaya, which has been maintained at over 5.0 km over the last 15 m.y. The dating of the fossilized plant assemblages involved U-Pb dating of zircons to provide age constraints for the Liuqu and Qiabulin paleofloras.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential sources for datasets that describe elevation and climate change along the Himalaya-Tibet orogen over the past 56 million years.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources for datasets include the Liuqu and Qiabulin paleofloras along the Yarlung-Zangpo suture, as well as the previously published paleoflora from the Namling Basin and several sea-level floras of similar ages from the Himalaya foreland basin. These sources collectively allow for charting elevation and climate change along the southern flank of the Himalaya-Tibet orogen over the past 56 million years.
